title: Money Conversations
description: Assess how comfortably you discuss money together

questions.text: I feel at ease when money comes up in conversation with my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Your emotional response when money comes up reveals how safe the topic feels. Tension or anxiety around money discussions often signals unspoken fears or past negative experiences.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels more tension, explore what creates that. The relaxed partner may be unaware they're triggering discomfort.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ease—or shared discomfort—means you're starting from the same place and can work on it together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What emotion do you notice when money comes up with your partner?

questions.text: I believe we can talk about money without it becoming a conflict.

therapeutic.rationale: Belief in your ability to discuss money calmly shapes how you approach these conversations. Pessimism here often becomes self-fulfilling—expecting conflict creates defensiveness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different confidence levels suggest different past experiences. The less confident partner may need reassurance that disagreement won't mean disaster.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared belief in your ability to discuss money calmly is a foundation to build on.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make money conversations feel safer for you?

questions.text: I trust my partner would listen if I had concerns about money.

therapeutic.rationale: Trust that you'll be heard is essential for raising financial concerns. Without it, worries go unspoken until they become resentments or crises.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: A trust gap here means one partner doesn't feel safe raising concerns. The other partner needs to create more space for difficult conversations.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust that concerns will be heard creates safety for honest financial communication.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Is there a money concern you've hesitated to raise? What holds you back?

questions.text: I'm confident we could work through a financial disagreement.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence in your ability to resolve financial disagreements reflects trust in your partnership. This optimism helps you approach differences as solvable rather than threatening.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is less confident, explore what's driving that doubt. Past experiences? Observed patterns? Naming it helps address it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in your ability to resolve financial differences is a relationship strength.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What gives you confidence—or doubt—about handling financial disagreements together?

questions.text: I see any money differences between us as workable, not worrying.

therapeutic.rationale: How you view your financial differences matters. Seeing them as workable promotes collaboration; seeing them as worrying creates anxiety and distance.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is more worried about differences, explore what specifically concerns them. Often it's not the difference itself but what it represents.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared perspective on your differences—whether optimistic or concerned—means you can address them together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What money differences between you feel workable? Which feel more concerning?
